Original_notes: to guard against pigs, fences are built
land belongs to the kindred, which reapportions it when necessary
(+); principal obligation of the chiefs was liberality – frequent public feasts
burial mound for king and chiefs (?)
semi-divine [underlined]; main prop of his authority was his claim of divine ancestry
(+); some of the ancient paramount chiefs were worshipped
(+); tribute [underlined]; I gather that such relationships existed, but Burrows (1936) never says so specifically

(+); "The death penalty and, perhaps, various forms of violence and mutilation may have been in use in the old days; but now that the supreme power is European, they have been abandoned". (+) [presence] seems more consistent with other data than (-) [absence]

(+); "The death penalty and, perhaps, various forms of violence and mutilation may have been in use in the old days; but now that the supreme power is European, they have been abandoned". (+) [presence] seems more consistent with other data than (-) [absence]

(-); Informants differ as to whether or not this trait is pre-European. Burrows (1936: 101) believes that before contact there were one or two "crop guards" in each village to catch taro thieves, but probably without other functions
3 lines of battle formed – youths, men, aged
(-); Kings as "tabernacles" of the gods – but primarily political specialists
(+); (-) by 1910, according to Mariner, who had talked to a Tongan informant at that time. No other information given.
(+); at the time of Burrow’s visit, the main use of canoes was to shuttle between Futuna and Alofi, 3 miles away, but I am guessing that much longer voyages were made
